{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3159545,"name":"Question all assumptions, search for truth.","username":"celttechie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/7feea3/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-07T22:09:33.957Z","cooked":"

With our arm mechanism we have two falcons, one controlling a separate section of arm. We have reverse and forward limit switches installed. We confirm with phoenix tuner that they get activated, show “closed” and stop the backward movement of the motor. We also have it zero the encoder when it hits the reverse limit. If we run it back to hit the limit and stop, using percentage control, then I can’t switch to position control and have it move to a positive value. It will start buzzing, and it’s hard to see, but it looks like maybe the amber lights blink away briefly, but then come back on repeatedly.
If we use percentage control to move away the motor from zero (positive percentage value), the encoder count goes up from zero, and THEN we can switch to position control and have it successfully move to the commanded position.
This happens on BOTH motors.
We have further been able to use Motion Magic on both motors to move to all positions, but again, it will not leave “home”, with encoder values at zero, unless we first move the motors away from zero.
I’ve even given it a position command, and while the motors are buzzing at zero, manually turn the screw until the motor takes over and decides to move to position.
Anybody have an idea what I should be looking for? I’m almost ready to swap out motors to see if they have an issue.

Also want to add that we typically move the mechanism at about 15% when using percent control, so it’s not like it can’t move the arm.

And we just have a P value set, with a neutral deadband of 2%

No, we were just testing it again tonight. I can run the motor back to home and the switch closes and makes the motor stop, just like it should. If I run the motor away from home, I can then command it to any position just fine.

OK, new information: I was wrong about it not coming away from the “homed” position using position control. It WILL move using position control, but WILL NOT when using motion magic.

So position control will move the arm sections with the given P value. I have Motion Magic set to an acceleration of 30000 and a velocity of 20000. I’m guessing since it’s supposed to start out slow it never gives it enough power to move out of the home position on that trapezoidal profile.

So do I give it a stronger P, or add I term so it has a stronger response to start with?
